instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2: What is SMC_PM_G2? This is a typo of SMC_PM_G2_EN When you see SMC_PM_G2, assume they meant to type SMC_PM_G2_EN.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
threads.message:
The board was in good condition, but it wouldn't turn on. PPBus had 8.2v and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> was low. Replaced the <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> and the Mac came back. It worked fine for two weeks and stopped.

The font pulses up to 0.160, as do some lines.

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.26V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 2.5v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 2.4v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.26V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5v (pulsating)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V (pulsating)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.37v

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL> _EN - 3.4V

I tried SMC bypass mode, it didn't work. I've already checked the SPI resistors.

I think it could be the SMC, but I don't have a replacement.

any tips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
threads.message:
Reballing and it didn't work. I got an SMC chip and replaced it.

I returned to the initial problem. PPBus 8.2v and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> low. The <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is fine, 100k. I have 3.42 on pin 1 and 0.6 on pin 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
threads.message:
Be sure no corrosion between J6100 pads.
Remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
If still low, replace <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
threads.message:
I had removed the J6100.

Without the <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>, the <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> remains low, even when replacing the <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>. I put the <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> back in place and now I have 3v. But PPBus remains 8.2v

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL> _EN - 0

Maybe the SMC chip I got is bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no fan, pulsing
threads.message:
With a "new" SMC, it worked again. Let's go to the tests.

Thank you very much for your help, once again!
